chatbot.model package

Submodules

chatbot.model.attention module

class chatbot.model.attention.AttnLayer(hidden_size: int, method: str = 'concat')

Bases: Module

An alignment attention layer for producing attention energies.

The implementation is based on the paper “Effective Approaches to Attention-based Neural Machine Translation”. Luong, M.-T., Pham, H., & Manning, C. D. (2015). https://arxiv.org/abs/1508.04025

Applies an alignment score method for computing the attention energies. The available alignment score methods are: concat, dot and general.

Parameters:

  • hidden_size (int) – Hidden size of Linear layer used in concat and general alignment function.

  • method (str, optional) – The name of the alignment function. Defaults to concat.

Inputs: decoder_output, encoder_state

  • decoder_output: tensor of shape \((1, N, H)\).

  • encoder_state: tensor of shape \((L, N, H)\)

where:

\[\begin{split}\begin{aligned} N ={} & \text{batch size} \\ L ={} & \text{max sequence length} \\ H ={} & \text{hidden_size} \end{aligned}\end{split}\]
Outputs: attention_energies

  • attention_energies: tensor of shape \((N, 1, L)\)

forward(decoder_output: Tensor, encoder_state: Tensor) → Tensor

The forward pass of the attention layer.

Parameters:

  • decoder_output (torch.Tensor) – The ith output of the decoder.

  • encoder_state (torch.Tensor) – The output of the encoder.

Returns:

The attention energies (weights).

Return type:

torch.Tensor

select_attention_score() → Callable[[Tensor, Tensor], Tensor]

Returns an alignment function for producing attention energies.

Available alignment functions: concat, dot, and general.

Returns:

A Callable alignment function.

  • params (Dict[str, Any]) – Initialization parameters for the selected decoder.

Returns:

Return type:

torch.nn.Module

Raises:

ValueError – If the provided decoder name does not exist.

class chatbot.model.decoders.LuongAttnDecoderGRU(alignment_method: str, embedding: Embedding, hidden_size: int, output_size: int, num_layers: int = 1, dropout: float = 0.1, temperature: float = 1.0)

Bases: Module

Decoder with GRU layer for a sequence-to-sequence model.

Produces a probability distribution predicting the next token in a sequence of tokens.

The decoder uses a global attention mechanism as described on the paper “Effective Approaches to Attention-based Neural Machine Translation”. Luong, M.-T., Pham, H., & Manning, C. D. (2015). https://arxiv.org/abs/1508.04025

Parameters:

  • alignment_method (str) – Name of the alignment score method used in the attention layer. The available methods are: concat, dot and general. (vocabulary size).

  • embedding (nn.Embedding) – The embedding layer.

  • hidden_size (int) – The number of features in the hidden state.

  • output_size (int) – The size of the vocabulary.

  • num_layers (int, optional) – The number of recurrent layers (default=1).

  • dropout (float, optional) – The dropout value applied to the embedded input sequence and to the GRU layer. If non-zero, the num_layers should be greater than 1, otherwise the dropout value will be set to zero. (default=0.1).

  • temperature (float, optional) – Used to control the randomness of the decoder’s predictions by scaling the logits before applying softmax. Must be greater than zero. If temperature = 1 there is no effect to the output logits (default=1).

Inputs: input_seq, h_0, encoder_state

  • input_seq: tensor of shape \((1, N)\).

  • h_0: tensor of shape \((num_layers, N, H)\).

  • encoder_state: tensor of shape \((L, N, H)\).

where:

\[\begin{split}\begin{aligned} N ={} & \text{batch size} \\ L ={} & \text{max sequence length} \\ H ={} & \text{hidden\_size} \end{aligned}\end{split}\]
Outputs: output, h_n

  • output: tensor of shape \((N, V)\).

  • h_n: tensor of shape \((num_layers, N, H)\).

where:

\[\begin{split}\begin{aligned} V ={} & \text{vocabulary size} \\ \end{aligned}\end{split}\]
forward(input_seq: Tensor, h_0: Tensor, encoder_state: Tensor) → Tuple[Tensor, Tensor]

The forward pass of the decoder.

Note

The decoder runs one step (token) at a time.

Parameters:

  • input_seq (torch.Tensor) – Batch of single token sequences.

  • h_0 (torch.Tensor) – The last hidden state of the encoder.

  • encoder_state (torch.Tensor) – The output of the encoder.

Returns:

The predictive distribution

and the attentional hidden state of the decoder.

Return type:

Tuple[torch.Tensor, torch.Tensor]

class chatbot.model.decoders.LuongAttnDecoderLSTM(alignment_method: str, embedding: Embedding, hidden_size: int, output_size: int, num_layers: int = 1, dropout: float = 0.1, temperature: float = 1.0)

Bases: Module

Decoder with LSTM layer for a sequence-to-sequence model.

Produces a probability distribution predicting the next token in a sequence of tokens.

The decoder uses a global attention mechanism as described on the paper “Effective Approaches to Attention-based Neural Machine Translation”. Luong, M.-T., Pham, H., & Manning, C. D. (2015). https://arxiv.org/abs/1508.04025

Parameters:

  • alignment_method (str) – Name of the alignment score method used in the attention layer. The available methods are: concat, dot and general. (vocabulary size).

  • embedding (nn.Embedding) – The embedding layer.

  • hidden_size (int) – The number of features in the hidden state.

  • output_size (int) – The size of the vocabulary.

  • num_layers (int, optional) – The number of recurrent layers (default=1).

  • dropout (float, optional) – The dropout value applied to the embedded input sequence and to the GRU layer. If non-zero, the num_layers should be greater than 1, otherwise the dropout value will be set to zero. (default=0.1).

  • temperature (float, optional) – Used to control the randomness of the decoder’s predictions by scaling the logits before applying softmax. Must be greater than zero. If temperature = 1 there is no effect to the output logits (default=1).

Inputs: input_seq, h_0, c_0, encoder_state

  • input_seq: tensor of shape \((1, N)\).

  • h_0: tensor of shape \((num_layers, N, H)\).

  • c_0: tensor of shape \((num_layers, N, H)\).

  • encoder_state: tensor of shape \((L, N, H)\).

where:

\[\begin{split}\begin{aligned} N ={} & \text{batch size} \\ L ={} & \text{max sequence length} \\ H ={} & \text{hidden\_size} \end{aligned}\end{split}\]
Outputs: output, h_n

  • output: tensor of shape \((N, V)\).

  • h_n: tensor of shape \((num_layers, N, H)\).

where:

\[\begin{split}\begin{aligned} V ={} & \text{vocabulary size} \\ \end{aligned}\end{split}\]
forward(input_seq: Tensor, h_0: Tensor, c_0: Tensor, encoder_state: Tensor) → Tuple[Tensor, Tensor, Tensor]

The forward pass of the decoder.

Note

The decoder runs one step (token) at a time.

Parameters:

  • input_seq (torch.Tensor) – Batch of single token sequences.

  • h_0 (torch.Tensor) – The last hidden state of the encoder.

  • c_0 (torch.Tensor) –

  • encoder_state (torch.Tensor) – The output of the encoder.

chatbot.model.embeddings module

class chatbot.model.embeddings.EmbeddingLayerConstructor

Bases: object

Responsible for initializing an nn.Embedding layer.

Initializes the embedding layer with either pretrained frozen weights from a file or with learnable weights.

Example

>>> from chatbot.models.embeddings import EmbeddingLayerConstructor
>>> embedding_init_params = {"embedding_dim": 100, "padding_idx": 0}
>>> embedding = EmbeddingLayerConstructor.create_embedding_layer(
...     vocab_tokens=["1st_token", "2nd_token", "and_so_on"],
...     filepath="./pretrained_embeddings/glove.6B.100d.txt",
...     **embedding_init_params
...     )
>>>
>>> embedding
classmethod create_embedding_layer(vocab_tokens: List[str], filepath: str | None = None, **kwargs) → Embedding

Initializes a nn.Embedding layer.

If filepath is provided the embedding layer is initialized with pretrained word embeddings from the file. Otherwise, returns an embedding layer with learnable weights.

Parameters:

  • vocab_tokens (List[str]) – All the tokens in the vocabulary.

  • filepath (str, optional) – Path to the pretrained embeddings file. Defaults to None.

  • **kwargs – Initialization parameters of the embedding layer, e.g., embedding_dim.

Returns:

An embedding layer with either pretrained

frozen weights or with learnable weights.

Return type:

nn.Embedding

classmethod from_file(vocab_tokens: List[str], filepath: str, **kwargs) → Embedding

Loads pretrained word embeddings, i.e., GLoVe embeddings, into a nn.Embedding layer.

Parameters:

  • vocab_tokens (List[str]) – All the tokens in the vocabulary.

  • filepath (str) – Path to the pretrained embeddings file.

  • **kwargs – Initialization parameters of the embedding layer, e.g., embedding_dim.

Returns:

An embedding layer with pretrained frozen weights.

Return type:

nn.Embedding

classmethod without_pretrained_embeddings(vocab_tokens: List[str], **kwargs) → Embedding

Returns an initialized nn.Embedding layer with learnable weights.

Parameters:

  • vocab_tokens (List[str]) – All the tokens in the vocabulary.

  • **kwargs – Initialization parameters of the embedding layer, e.g., embedding_dim.

Returns:

An embedding layer with learnable weights.

Return type:

nn.Embedding

class chatbot.model.embeddings.PreTrainedEmbeddings(word_to_index: Dict[str, int], word_vectors: List[Tensor])

Bases: object

A wrapper around pretrained word vectors and their use.

Loads the pretrained embeddings from a file and creates an embedding matrix ready to be passed into an nn.Embedding layer.

Parameters:

  • word_to_index (Dict[str, int]) – A mapping from words to indexes.

  • word_vectors (List[torch.Tensors]) – List with word embeddings.

word_to_index

A mapping from words to indexes.

Type:

Dict[str, int]

word_vectors

List with word embeddings.

Type:

List[torch.Tensors]

index_to_word

A mapping from indexes to words.

Type:

Dict[int, str]

Example

>>> # Example loading glove embeddings
>>> embeddings_wrapper = PreTrainedEmbeddings.from_embeddings_file(
...     embedding_file="./.vector_cache/glove.6B.100d.txt"
... )
>>> word_vectors = embeddings_wrapper.word_vectors
>>> word_to_index = embeddings_wrapper.word_to_index
>>> index_to_word = embeddings_wrapper.index_to_word
>>> print(len(word_vectors))
400000
>>> print(word_vectors[0].shape)
torch.Size([100])

>>> # Create an embedding matrix for a given list of words
>>> embeddings_matrix = embeddings_wrapper.make_embedding_matrix(
...     words=["Creating", "a", "matrix"]
... )
>>> print(embeddings_matrix.shape)
torch.Size([3, 100])

>>> # Get embedding for a single word
>>> cat_embedding = embeddings_wrapper.get_embedding(word="cat")
>>> print(cat_embedding)
tensor([0.2309, 0.2828, 0.6318, 0.5941, 0.5860, 0.6326, 0.2440, 0.1411,
 0.0608, -0.7898, -0.2910,  0.1429,  0.7227,  0.2043,  0.1407,  0.9876,
 0.5253,  0.0975,  0.8822,  0.5122,  0.4020,  0.2117, -0.0131, -0.7162,
 0.5539,  1.1452, -0.8804, -0.5022, -0.2281,  0.0239,  0.1072,  0.0837,
 0.5501,  0.5848,  0.7582,  0.4571, -0.2800,  0.2522,  0.6896, -0.6097,
 0.1958,  0.0442, -0.3114, -0.6883, -0.2272,  0.4618, -0.7716,  0.1021,
 0.5564,  0.0674, -0.5721,  0.2374,  0.4717,  0.8277, -0.2926, -1.3422,
-0.0993,  0.2814,  0.4160,  0.1058,  0.6220,  0.8950, -0.2345,  0.5135,

-0.0072,  0.3302, -0.1236,  0.2719, -0.4095,  0.0219, -0.6069,  0.4076,

-0.7368, -0.1453,  0.1510, -0.7149])
classmethod from_embeddings_file(embedding_file: str) → PreTrainedEmbeddings

Instantiates the wrapper from a pre-trained vector file.

Vector file should have the following format:

word0 x0_0 x0_1 x0_2 x0_3 ... x0_N
word1 x1_0 x1_1 x1_2 x1_3 ... x1_N
Parameters:

embedding_file (str) – The path to the embedding file.

Returns:

An instance of the PretrainedEmbeddings class.

Return type:

PreTrainedEmbeddings

get_embedding(word: str) → Tensor

Returns the embedding of the input word.

Parameters:

word (str) – The input word to be embedded.

Returns:

The word embedding.

Return type:

torch.Tensor

make_embedding_matrix(words: List[str]) → Tensor

Creates an embedding matrix for a specific set of words.

Parameters:

words (List[str]) – A list of words.

Returns: final_embeddings

  • final_embeddings: tensor of shape \((V, D)\).

where:

\[\begin{split}\begin{aligned} N ={} & \text{vocabulary size} \\ D ={} & \text{dimension of token embeddings} \end{aligned}\end{split}\]

chatbot.model.encoders module

class chatbot.model.encoders.EncoderGRU(embedding: Embedding, hidden_size: int, num_layers: int = 1, dropout: float = 0)

Bases: Module

Encoder with a bidirectional GRU layer for a sequence-to-sequence model.

Encodes a batch of variable-length query sequences, comprised of tokens, into a fixed-length vector representation.

Parameters:

  • embedding (nn.Embedding) – The embedding layer.

  • hidden_size (int) – The number of features in the hidden state.

  • num_layers (int, optional) – The number of GRU layers (default=1).

  • dropout (float, optional) – The dropout value applied to the GRU layer. If non-zero, the num_layers should be greater than 1, otherwise the dropout value will be set to zero. (default=0).

Inputs: x_queries, query_lengths, h_0

  • x_queries: tensor of shape \((L, N)\).

  • query_lengths: tensor of shape \((N)\).

  • h_0: tensor of shape \((2 * \text{num_layers}, H)\)

or \((2 * \text{num_layers}, N, H)\) containing the initial hidden state for the input sequence. Defaults to None.

where:

\[\begin{split}\begin{aligned} N ={} & \text{batch size} \\ L ={} & \text{max sequence length} \\ H ={} & \text{hidden_size} \end{aligned}\end{split}\]
Outputs: output, h_n

  • output: tensor of shape \((L, N, H)\).

  • h_n: tensor of shape \((2 * \text{num_layers}, N, H)\).

hidden_size

The number of features in the hidden state h.

Type:

int

emb

The embedding layer for the input sequence.

Type:

torch.nn.Module

bi_gru

A bidirectional GRU layer.

Type:

torch.nn.Module

forward(x_queries: Tensor, query_lengths: Tensor, h_0: Tensor | None = None) → Tuple[Tensor, Tensor]

The forward pass of the encoder.

Parameters:

  • x_queries (torch.Tensor) – A batch of input sequences.

  • query_lengths (torch.Tensor) – Holds the length of each input sequence.

  • h_0 (torch.Tensor, optional) – Initial hidden state of the rnn layer of the encoder. Defaults to None.

Returns:

Output and hidden

state of the encoder layer.

Return type:

Tuple[torch.Tensor, torch.Tensor]

class chatbot.model.encoders.EncoderLSTM(embedding: Embedding, hidden_size: int, num_layers: int = 1, dropout: float = 0)

Bases: Module

Encoder with a bidirectional LSTM layer for a sequence-to-sequence model.

Encodes a batch of variable-length query sequences, comprised of tokens, into a fixed-length vector representation.

Parameters:

  • embedding (nn.Embedding) – The embedding layer.

  • hidden_size (int) – The number of features in the hidden state.

  • num_layers (int, optional) – The number of recurrent layers (default=1).

  • dropout (float, optional) – The dropout value applied to the GRU layer. If non-zero, the num_layers should be greater than 1, otherwise the dropout value will be set to zero. (default=0).

Inputs: x_queries, query_lengths, h_0

  • x_queries: tensor of shape \((L, N)\).

  • query_lengths: tensor of shape \((N)\).

  • h_0: tensor of shape \((2 * \text{num_layers}, H)\) or \((2 * \text{num_layers}, N, H)\) containing the initial hidden state for the input sequence. Defaults to None.

where:

\[\begin{split}\begin{aligned} N ={} & \text{batch size} \\ L ={} & \text{max sequence length} \\ H ={} & \text{hidden_size} \end{aligned}\end{split}\]
Outputs: output, h_n, c_n

  • output: tensor of shape \((L, N, H)\).

  • h_n: tensor of shape \((2 * \text{num_layers}, N, H)\).

  • c_n: tensor of shape \((2 * \text{num_layers}, N, H)\).

hidden_size

The number of features in the hidden state h.

Type:

int

emb

The embedding layer for the input sequence.

Type:

torch.nn.Module

bi_lstm

A bidirectional LSTM layer.

Type:

torch.nn.Module

forward(x_queries: Tensor, query_lengths: Tensor, h_0: Tensor | None = None) → Tuple[Tensor, Tensor, Tensor]

The forward pass of the encoder.

Parameters:

  • x_queries (torch.Tensor) – A batch of input sequences.

  • query_lengths (torch.Tensor) – Holds the length of each input sequence.

  • h_0 (torch.Tensor, optional) – Initial hidden state of the rnn layer of the encoder. Defaults to None.

Returns:

Output

,cell, and hidden state of the encoder layer.

Return type:

Tuple[torch.Tensor, torch.Tensor, torch.Tensor]

chatbot.model.samplers module

class chatbot.model.samplers.GreedySearchSampler(encoder: Module, decoder: Module, eos_idx: int)

Bases: Module

Implements greedy search decoding.

Selects the most probable token, i.e argmax from the model’s vocabulary at each decoding time-step as candidate to the output sequence.

Parameters:

  • encoder (torch.nn.Module) – The encoder layer of a seq-to-seq model.

  • decoder (torch.nn.Module) – The decoder layer of a seq-to-seq model.

  • eos_idx (int) – The end-of-sentence token index.

Inputs: input_seq, query_length, max_seq_length

  • input_seq: tensor of shape \((L_{in}, 1)\).

  • query_length: tensor of shape \((1, )\).

  • max_seq_length: An integer number.

Outputs: all_token_indices

  • all_token_indices: tensor of shape \((L_{out})\).

where:

\[\begin{split}\begin{aligned} L_{in} ={} & \text{input sequence length} \\ L_{out} ={} & \text{max_seq_length} \end{aligned}\end{split}\]
forward(input_seq: Tensor, query_length: Tensor, max_seq_length: int) → Tensor

Forward pass of the Greedy Search Sampler.

Parameters:

  • input_seq (torch.Tensor) – Input tokenized sequence.

  • query_length (torch.Tensor) – Length of input sequence.

  • max_seq_length (int) – The maximum sequence length in the entire dataset.

Returns:

The predicted output indices.

Return type:

torch.Tensor

class chatbot.model.samplers.RandomSearchSampler(encoder: Module, decoder: Module, eos_idx: int)

Bases: Module

Implements multinomial sampling search during decoding.

Samples a token according to the output probability distribution over the vocabulary.

Parameters:

  • encoder (torch.nn.Module) – The encoder layer of a seq-to-seq model.

  • decoder (torch.nn.Module) – The decoder layer of a seq-to-seq model.

  • eos_idx (int) – The end-of-sentence token index.

Inputs: input_seq, query_length, max_seq_length

  • input_seq: tensor of shape \((L_{in}, 1)\).

  • query_length: tensor of shape \((1, )\).

  • max_seq_length: An integer number.

Outputs: all_token_indices

  • all_token_indices: tensor of shape \((L_{out})\).

where:

\[\begin{split}\begin{aligned} L_{in} ={} & \text{input sequence length} \\ L_{out} ={} & \text{max_seq_length} \end{aligned}\end{split}\]
forward(input_seq: Tensor, query_length: Tensor, max_seq_length: int) → Tensor

Forward pass of the Greedy Search Sampler.

Parameters:

  • input_seq (torch.Tensor) – Input tokenized sequence.

  • query_length (torch.Tensor) – Length of input sequence.

  • max_seq_length (int) – The maximum sequence length in the entire dataset.

Returns:

The predicted token indices

along with their predicted scores.

Return type:

Tuple[torch.Tensor, torch.Tensor]

class chatbot.model.AttnLayer(hidden_size: int, method: str = 'concat')

Bases: Module

An alignment attention layer for producing attention energies.

The implementation is based on the paper “Effective Approaches to Attention-based Neural Machine Translation”. Luong, M.-T., Pham, H., & Manning, C. D. (2015). https://arxiv.org/abs/1508.04025

Applies an alignment score method for computing the attention energies. The available alignment score methods are: concat, dot and general.

Parameters:

  • hidden_size (int) – Hidden size of Linear layer used in concat and general alignment function.

  • method (str, optional) – The name of the alignment function. Defaults to concat.

Inputs: decoder_output, encoder_state

  • decoder_output: tensor of shape \((1, N, H)\).

  • encoder_state: tensor of shape \((L, N, H)\)

where:

\[\begin{split}\begin{aligned} N ={} & \text{batch size} \\ L ={} & \text{max sequence length} \\ H ={} & \text{hidden_size} \end{aligned}\end{split}\]
Outputs: attention_energies

  • attention_energies: tensor of shape \((N, 1, L)\)

forward(decoder_output: Tensor, encoder_state: Tensor) → Tensor

The forward pass of the attention layer.

Parameters:

  • decoder_output (torch.Tensor) – The ith output of the decoder.

  • encoder_state (torch.Tensor) – The output of the encoder.

Returns:

The attention energies (weights).

Return type:

torch.Tensor

select_attention_score() → Callable[[Tensor, Tensor], Tensor]

Returns an alignment function for producing attention energies.

Available alignment functions: concat, dot, and general.

Returns:

A Callable alignment function.

class chatbot.model.EmbeddingLayerConstructor

Bases: object

Responsible for initializing an nn.Embedding layer.

Initializes the embedding layer with either pretrained frozen weights from a file or with learnable weights.

Example

>>> from chatbot.models.embeddings import EmbeddingLayerConstructor
>>> embedding_init_params = {"embedding_dim": 100, "padding_idx": 0}
>>> embedding = EmbeddingLayerConstructor.create_embedding_layer(
...     vocab_tokens=["1st_token", "2nd_token", "and_so_on"],
...     filepath="./pretrained_embeddings/glove.6B.100d.txt",
...     **embedding_init_params
...     )
>>>
>>> embedding
classmethod create_embedding_layer(vocab_tokens: List[str], filepath: str | None = None, **kwargs) → Embedding

Initializes a nn.Embedding layer.

If filepath is provided the embedding layer is initialized with pretrained word embeddings from the file. Otherwise, returns an embedding layer with learnable weights.

Parameters:

  • vocab_tokens (List[str]) – All the tokens in the vocabulary.

  • filepath (str, optional) – Path to the pretrained embeddings file. Defaults to None.

  • **kwargs – Initialization parameters of the embedding layer, e.g., embedding_dim.

Returns:

An embedding layer with either pretrained

frozen weights or with learnable weights.

Return type:

nn.Embedding

class chatbot.model.EncoderGRU(embedding: Embedding, hidden_size: int, num_layers: int = 1, dropout: float = 0)

Bases: Module

Encoder with a bidirectional GRU layer for a sequence-to-sequence model.

Encodes a batch of variable-length query sequences, comprised of tokens, into a fixed-length vector representation.

Parameters:

  • embedding (nn.Embedding) – The embedding layer.

  • hidden_size (int) – The number of features in the hidden state.

  • num_layers (int, optional) – The number of GRU layers (default=1).

  • dropout (float, optional) – The dropout value applied to the GRU layer. If non-zero, the num_layers should be greater than 1, otherwise the dropout value will be set to zero. (default=0).

Inputs: x_queries, query_lengths, h_0

  • x_queries: tensor of shape \((L, N)\).

  • query_lengths: tensor of shape \((N)\).

  • h_0: tensor of shape \((2 * \text{num_layers}, H)\)

or \((2 * \text{num_layers}, N, H)\) containing the initial hidden state for the input sequence. Defaults to None.

where:

\[\begin{split}\begin{aligned} N ={} & \text{batch size} \\ L ={} & \text{max sequence length} \\ H ={} & \text{hidden_size} \end{aligned}\end{split}\]
Outputs: output, h_n

  • output: tensor of shape \((L, N, H)\).

  • h_n: tensor of shape \((2 * \text{num_layers}, N, H)\).

hidden_size

The number of features in the hidden state h.

Type:

int

emb

The embedding layer for the input sequence.

Type:

torch.nn.Module

bi_gru

A bidirectional GRU layer.

Type:

torch.nn.Module

forward(x_queries: Tensor, query_lengths: Tensor, h_0: Tensor | None = None) → Tuple[Tensor, Tensor]

The forward pass of the encoder.

Parameters:

  • x_queries (torch.Tensor) – A batch of input sequences.

  • query_lengths (torch.Tensor) – Holds the length of each input sequence.

  • h_0 (torch.Tensor, optional) – Initial hidden state of the rnn layer of the encoder. Defaults to None.

Returns:

Output and hidden

state of the encoder layer.

Return type:

Tuple[torch.Tensor, torch.Tensor]

class chatbot.model.GreedySearchSampler(encoder: Module, decoder: Module, eos_idx: int)

Bases: Module

Implements greedy search decoding.

Selects the most probable token, i.e argmax from the model’s vocabulary at each decoding time-step as candidate to the output sequence.

Parameters:

  • encoder (torch.nn.Module) – The encoder layer of a seq-to-seq model.

  • decoder (torch.nn.Module) – The decoder layer of a seq-to-seq model.

  • eos_idx (int) – The end-of-sentence token index.

Inputs: input_seq, query_length, max_seq_length

  • input_seq: tensor of shape \((L_{in}, 1)\).

  • query_length: tensor of shape \((1, )\).

  • max_seq_length: An integer number.

Outputs: all_token_indices

  • all_token_indices: tensor of shape \((L_{out})\).

where:

\[\begin{split}\begin{aligned} L_{in} ={} & \text{input sequence length} \\ L_{out} ={} & \text{max_seq_length} \end{aligned}\end{split}\]
forward(input_seq: Tensor, query_length: Tensor, max_seq_length: int) → Tensor

Forward pass of the Greedy Search Sampler.

Parameters:

  • input_seq (torch.Tensor) – Input tokenized sequence.

  • query_length (torch.Tensor) – Length of input sequence.

  • max_seq_length (int) – The maximum sequence length in the entire dataset.

Returns:

The predicted output indices.

Return type:

torch.Tensor

class chatbot.model.LuongAttnDecoderGRU(alignment_method: str, embedding: Embedding, hidden_size: int, output_size: int, num_layers: int = 1, dropout: float = 0.1, temperature: float = 1.0)

Bases: Module

Decoder with GRU layer for a sequence-to-sequence model.

Produces a probability distribution predicting the next token in a sequence of tokens.

The decoder uses a global attention mechanism as described on the paper “Effective Approaches to Attention-based Neural Machine Translation”. Luong, M.-T., Pham, H., & Manning, C. D. (2015). https://arxiv.org/abs/1508.04025

Parameters:

  • alignment_method (str) – Name of the alignment score method used in the attention layer. The available methods are: concat, dot and general. (vocabulary size).

  • embedding (nn.Embedding) – The embedding layer.

  • hidden_size (int) – The number of features in the hidden state.

  • output_size (int) – The size of the vocabulary.

  • num_layers (int, optional) – The number of recurrent layers (default=1).

  • dropout (float, optional) – The dropout value applied to the embedded input sequence and to the GRU layer. If non-zero, the num_layers should be greater than 1, otherwise the dropout value will be set to zero. (default=0.1).

  • temperature (float, optional) – Used to control the randomness of the decoder’s predictions by scaling the logits before applying softmax. Must be greater than zero. If temperature = 1 there is no effect to the output logits (default=1).

Inputs: input_seq, h_0, encoder_state

  • input_seq: tensor of shape \((1, N)\).

  • h_0: tensor of shape \((num_layers, N, H)\).

  • encoder_state: tensor of shape \((L, N, H)\).

where:

\[\begin{split}\begin{aligned} N ={} & \text{batch size} \\ L ={} & \text{max sequence length} \\ H ={} & \text{hidden\_size} \end{aligned}\end{split}\]
Outputs: output, h_n

  • output: tensor of shape \((N, V)\).

  • h_n: tensor of shape \((num_layers, N, H)\).

where:

\[\begin{split}\begin{aligned} V ={} & \text{vocabulary size} \\ \end{aligned}\end{split}\]
forward(input_seq: Tensor, h_0: Tensor, encoder_state: Tensor) → Tuple[Tensor, Tensor]

The forward pass of the decoder.

Note

The decoder runs one step (token) at a time.

Parameters:

  • input_seq (torch.Tensor) – Batch of single token sequences.

  • h_0 (torch.Tensor) – The last hidden state of the encoder.

  • encoder_state (torch.Tensor) – The output of the encoder.

Returns:

The predictive distribution

and the attentional hidden state of the decoder.

Return type:

Tuple[torch.Tensor, torch.Tensor]

class chatbot.model.PreTrainedEmbeddings(word_to_index: Dict[str, int], word_vectors: List[Tensor])

Bases: object

A wrapper around pretrained word vectors and their use.

Loads the pretrained embeddings from a file and creates an embedding matrix ready to be passed into an nn.Embedding layer.

Parameters:

  • word_to_index (Dict[str, int]) – A mapping from words to indexes.

  • word_vectors (List[torch.Tensors]) – List with word embeddings.

word_to_index

A mapping from words to indexes.

Type:

Dict[str, int]

word_vectors

List with word embeddings.

Type:

List[torch.Tensors]

index_to_word

A mapping from indexes to words.

Type:

Dict[int, str]

Example

>>> # Example loading glove embeddings
>>> embeddings_wrapper = PreTrainedEmbeddings.from_embeddings_file(
...     embedding_file="./.vector_cache/glove.6B.100d.txt"
... )
>>> word_vectors = embeddings_wrapper.word_vectors
>>> word_to_index = embeddings_wrapper.word_to_index
>>> index_to_word = embeddings_wrapper.index_to_word
>>> print(len(word_vectors))
400000
>>> print(word_vectors[0].shape)
torch.Size([100])

>>> # Create an embedding matrix for a given list of words
>>> embeddings_matrix = embeddings_wrapper.make_embedding_matrix(
...     words=["Creating", "a", "matrix"]
... )
>>> print(embeddings_matrix.shape)
torch.Size([3, 100])

>>> # Get embedding for a single word
>>> cat_embedding = embeddings_wrapper.get_embedding(word="cat")
>>> print(cat_embedding)
tensor([0.2309, 0.2828, 0.6318, 0.5941, 0.5860, 0.6326, 0.2440, 0.1411,

 0.5539,  1.1452, -0.8804, -0.5022, -0.2281,  0.0239,  0.1072,  0.0837,
 0.5501,  0.5848,  0.7582,  0.4571, -0.2800,  0.2522,  0.6896, -0.6097,
 0.1958,  0.0442, -0.3114, -0.6883, -0.2272,  0.4618, -0.7716,  0.1021,

classmethod from_embeddings_file(embedding_file: str) → PreTrainedEmbeddings

Instantiates the wrapper from a pre-trained vector file.

Vector file should have the following format:

word0 x0_0 x0_1 x0_2 x0_3 ... x0_N
word1 x1_0 x1_1 x1_2 x1_3 ... x1_N
Parameters:

embedding_file (str) – The path to the embedding file.

Returns:

An instance of the PretrainedEmbeddings class.

class chatbot.model.RandomSearchSampler(encoder: Module, decoder: Module, eos_idx: int)

Bases: Module

Implements multinomial sampling search during decoding.

Samples a token according to the output probability distribution over the vocabulary.

Parameters:

  • encoder (torch.nn.Module) – The encoder layer of a seq-to-seq model.

  • decoder (torch.nn.Module) – The decoder layer of a seq-to-seq model.

  • eos_idx (int) – The end-of-sentence token index.

Inputs: input_seq, query_length, max_seq_length

  • input_seq: tensor of shape \((L_{in}, 1)\).

  • query_length: tensor of shape \((1, )\).

  • max_seq_length: An integer number.

Outputs: all_token_indices

  • all_token_indices: tensor of shape \((L_{out})\).

where:

\[\begin{split}\begin{aligned} L_{in} ={} & \text{input sequence length} \\ L_{out} ={} & \text{max_seq_length} \end{aligned}\end{split}\]

  • query_length (torch.Tensor) – Length of input sequence.

  • max_seq_length (int) – The maximum sequence length in the entire dataset.

along with their predicted scores.
